149509279.review: Battle Ram is an exciting action-packed game that will provide hours of entertainment for players of all skill levels. Its unique concept of a powerful lamb fighting robots offers a refreshing change from typical shooters or RPGs.

149497845.review: An addictive game where you control a powerful lamb while fighting robots. Unique gameplay, music and a variety of levels provide hours of fun. Conduct strategic battles in the secret laboratory and on the proving ground using only the mouse for control. Despite the small number of levels, the difficulty guarantees hours of exciting gameplay. The game invites you to a world of exciting combat adventures!

149467812.review:
As an avid gamer, I always find myself on the lookout for the next big hit. Well, look no further, because Battle Ram has quickly become my go-to game for thrilling battles and strategic victories. Let me tell you why I can't get enough of it!

First and foremost, the graphics in Battle Ram are absolutely stunning. The attention to detail in the character design, landscapes, and battle sequences is truly commendable. Every swing of my sword, every thunderous roar of my army charging into battle, is brought to life with incredible visual effects. It's an immersive experience that truly makes me feel like I'm commanding a legendary army.

Now, onto the gameplay itself. Battle Ram's mechanics are easy to grasp, yet challenging enough to keep me engaged for hours on end. The combat system is well-balanced, offering a wide range of strategies to master. From forming alliances with other players to launching surprise attacks on enemy bases, the possibilities are endless. The game also rewards careful planning and resource management, which adds a layer of depth that keeps me constantly strategizing.

149221741.review:
Finally we can find out who will win in a fight between a bunch of robots and a sheep lookin' horny guy!

In all seriousness I can only recommend this when it's on sale.
It's too short and the main challenge is fighting with the floaty controls, which considering this is basically a bullet hell where you die if you slide into the side of the play area, make for a rather frustrating experience.
The other game play element is timing, where taking risks by trying to play fast is usually punished, which makes the game just feel a bit slow especially as the levels progress and the enemies keep getting tankier.

Also it's missing polish, there are no volume sliders, only an on/off toggle and there's some glitchy stuff going on with the death overlay when playing on higher resolutions.

3/10 as a game overall (very average, shallow, and short), but 7/10 for what it is.

Would ram again.

147013127.review:
Unfortunately I didn't really enjoy Battle Ram. Games like these live or die by their central mechanic, since that's what they are all about, and I found that to be tedious in this game. It's all about ramming into enemies non-stop while dodging bullets and timing their attacks (they have no wind-up). You often had to ram into enemy types later on upwards of 10-20 times, so it became monotonous for me. Timing attacks with no wind-up also means you kinda just end up clicking enemies a safe number of times, and then move away, move in a circle, rinse and repeat. Also, enemy variety seems to center around the same enemies but more bullets and much more spongy.

A game like Hayai is far superior imo, which boasts a nuanced and yet similarly simple system. If you are making a simple, one-mechanic game like this, it better be real good. 

That said, I apprecaite the style of the game. The ram and the music is fun and different, so the aesthetic felt fresh.

141573793.review:
Pros: 
Playful cartoony design, 
Somewhat of a replayability factor,
Badass trading cards.

Cons: 
Lack of a confirmation button when deleting save data,
Unreliable bullet and character hitboxes,
Enemy design feels very uninspired after a certain point,
No way to turn the annoying sound effects down without muting all sound,
Inconsistency in difficulty scaling.

Verdict: 
Worth buying only during a sale for a couple hours of grinding to get the achievements and trading cards.

While the first 10 chapters of the game are good, the last 10 chapters turn into a waiting simulator.
I got so bored that every minute that the game didn't end felt like torture.
There are also some hitbox bugs in the game and the interface is bad.
There is no volume down setting.
There are two reasons why I gave the game a negative vote:
1) It waits 10 seconds to start the game when you die (take an example from super meat boy in games where we die all the time)
2) The balance of the game is very bad. 10-15 levels are extremely difficult while 15-20 levels are extremely easy/simple.

135619560.review:
When you need to kill some time it's ok. It's specifically meant for that = a quick and simple game for quick entertainment. 
It's a very short bullet hell. But....keep in mind....the levels get harder and harder...the last 5 are hard. 
Only 5.4% of players defeated the last level ( I know because it says so in the achievement I got). 

There are some issues: 1) the movement resembles ice skating so it's not easy to control the ram. 
2) when it dashes....it often goes too far and often out of the circle ( which means death ). 
3) often when you hit an enemy the ram bounces too far and out of the circle or on an enemy bullet. 
You have only 1 health point but unlimited amount of lives. You can resume on the level where you died so it's not a big deal. 
So it's quick fun but not enough for a recommendation.

Difficulty and limited space to move is fine; paper-thing models are, too, if that was the intent, but my single biggest gripe is how the screen shakes *immensely* whenever there's an explosion (constantly). It's painful to focus with the constant jarring of the screen & it makes steadily moving around enemies more of a pain than it really should be; really wouldn't mind a toggle for the shaking.
Overall fine for the price & entertaining, as well as cute, but again.... the shaking is unnecessary & I can't complain much otherwise. Thank you, devs!!

132400963.review:
The good: quirky, cute graphics

The bad: literally everything else
_______

There's a core of a good game here, but virtually every design choice sparks frustration. Let's just make a list:

1) All of the enemies' shots end in an explosion with ENORMOUS and unreasonable splash damage
2) You have no idea where the shots are going to stop
3) There is no cue (visual or audio) as to when enemies are going to fire...you just have to time it in your head
4) All of the graphics are large, and when things get busy, there's literally no room to move
5) You're trapped in a sumo-like ring, and if you go outside of it, you die
6) The enemies are not limited by the ring, and you can't kill them by bumping them outside of it (note: this would have actually been fun gameplay)
7) Literally everything one-shot kills you, while you have to hit everything else many, many times (all while dodging the no-warning shots and all of the splash damage)
8) Movement is done 100% by mouse twitch, and you'll either be moving too slowly to get away from stuff or go flying outside of the ring because you attempted to dodge quickly
9) Horizontal "ram" attempts will miss at least 50% of the time because of the way hit boxes are designed (and they strongly favor your opponents, who do not share the challenge due to the splashy weapons), so you'll spend your time constantly trying to line up enemies vertically to hit them rather than just go rushing past them (and probably out of the stupid ring)

Any one or two of these factors on their own, alongside more interesting gameplay, would have potentially been ok. Lots of splash damage from shots landing everywhere? At least give me the whole screen (like the enemies have) so that it truly can be a dodge-em game and I can run until I have an opening for an attack. Want to have a ring of death? Cool! Let me fight enemies that I can also bump out of the ring! You really, really want the ring of death plus splashy weapons? Ok, ok, fine, but at least shrink the graphics so that there's room to move, give the player fair hit boxes that work horizontally, and some kind of tighter controls so that they have a fighting chance!

As things stand, every design choice is created to induce rage, not enjoyment. The cutesy graphics can't save it. The game is unfun, and you shouldn't bother with it unless you're just a masochist who is really into screaming at their screen for hours while trying to 100% a poorly-designed game.

131316492.review: And so, this brave Battle Ram embarks on an epic quest to "gore" all the robots in sight. The intense battles can't get any more thrilling as they take place in the game arena with no way to escape. It's a battle of wits and resilience as our Battle Ram hero needs to dodge the attacks from the robots while trying to take them all down. As the game progresses, the challenge increases with the robots getting upgraded and more of them swarming to put an end to our ram's journey. But no matter how tough it gets, there is always that cheerful music in the background encouraging our Battle Ram to go on!

This is that type of game that will keep you screaming and retrying "just one more time".
The rules are simple: you control a badass ram with your mouse, and you have to destroy the enemies that enter inside the circle. If you leave the circle, you lose.
Starts easy but soon evolves into a super tight bullet hell where you must evade and time your attacks between bullets.
It's a cut, fun and hard game.

116157877.review:
Full review at: https://thegamehoard.com/2022/05/28/battle-ram-pc/

The danger of a one hit kill ending the level instantly is what gives Battle Ram its thrills, a save system helping it avoid frustration as you reach later levels that demand more cautious responsive play. The small set of robot foes encourages the player to evaluate the threat and pick their openings, the process simple since the variables are limited but the action still about more than clicking your mouse to smash your face into things wildly. The endurance levels do feel like they lack teeth and the some later robots seem more durable then they need to be, but other ideas like the dangerous detonation on death for robots and the friendly fire between them add some appreciated extra considerations to this solid little experience.

(Note, this review came after updates to the game that improved it a fair bit)

Las Mecánicas son interesantes y refrescantes, si sales del área circular segura el pequeño carnero quedara desparramado, literalmente,  debes tener mucho cuidado cada vez que planees embestir como si no hubiera un mañana, ya que el infierno de balas mezclado con muchos enemigos haciendo movimientos aleatorios podría llevarte a una muerte rápida e inesperada.

109822634.review: Such a cute game. Highly recommend!

109269816.review: I was having fun early on in the game, because I equated my constant dying to a lack of skill: Of course, I was a beginner. Even if I still am, it's not hard to see some of the issues with the game. First off, the ram isn't your mouse, it merely follows it. So at all times, you are effectively controlling the right-most side of the character, and of course, the rest of the hit box is on the rest of the character. In a bullet hell game with dodging as a primary mechanic, I don't think the player should have such little control over the positioning of the character. In a game about precision, your Ram also dashes further than where you clicked, so you have no real way to know where it'll end up, including out of bounds or into a bullet. The next big thing is the later levels. Instead of making the game genuinely difficult as you progress, it just swaps the color palette of previously seen enemies and gives them double or triple the health. It wasn't difficult anymore, just really tedious to wait, attack a few times, wait again, attack a few times. Tedium isn't difficulty! I tend to love smaller rogue-lites, with a cool gimmick. I have 15 hours on such a game, Lost Potato, which I truly recommend. I'll most likely beat this game, maybe come back and change this review, but as of now I'm not really having any fun. Sorry!

93069134.review:
In a very secret laboratory, the perfect weapon was being developed. And as a result of numerous experiments, scientists brought out a powerful creature - the Battle Ram. And now the ram must be tested at a military training ground. He has to fight robots.

So what exactly is Battle Ram? This is a lamb that runs around the arena. The character is controlled with the mouse. And all he can do is butt, he has no secret weapon. Actually, this is his main and only skill. The character runs around the arena, colliding with opponents. The musical accompaniment in the game is very cheerful and rhythmic. The game supports Russian.

The environment in the game can be attributed to the style of animation. You can choose the following characteristics: puzzle, arcade, sports game, single player, difficult game.

The game currently has only eight levels. Despite the small number of levels, the game is difficult. The difficulty of the game is that every time you lose, you start the battle from the very beginning.

The game gives quite a lot of emotions, both positive and negative. Because the game is built according to such a scheme as "easy too liarm". That is, we easily understand the rules by which it must be passed, but it will take a lot of time to hone the technique and pass the tests. A lot of games on Dendy were built on the same principle.

Let's consider in more detail the game by levels. The first level is training. In the second level, opponents are trying to hit the character with bullets. The next level is rocket, when missiles explode when hitting a player or just hitting each other. This is a fairly simple level, because the player just needs to dodge missiles. In the fourth level, you can be not only hit by bullets, but also pushed out of the field, which is also considered a loss. You need to be opponents in this level from the middle of the arena, after they have fired shots. Level with lasers is quite easy to pass. As in the third level, the player will need dexterity to dodge in time. In the seventh level, robots are passive, which shoot with just one shot, but there are quite a few of them. In the last level, a hardcore carnage begins. It involves all kinds of robots and strikes

84624000.review:
[h1]A fun action arena game with one important (for me) flaw.[/h1]

You are the Battle Ram. You're forced to stay within a circle and fight robots who try to blow you up. Ramming them repeatedly will kill them.

Touching the robots doesn't kill you: just leaving the area or getting shot/blown. All robots also explode on death. Every few levels the game mixes it up with "environmental hazards" like rockets and burning laser beams to dodge while fighting at the same time.

[i]EDIT: Originally played and reviewed in Jan 2021, a recent update has allowed me to change my review to a positive recommendation.[/i]

[h1]About enemies and gameplay[/h1]

There's several sorts of enemies from simple moving blocks to walking shooters and flying machines that shoot multiple times in a row.

When three robots cluster bomb the area, it can get pretty involved. The screenshakes from the explosions make it particularly hectic, and it's easy to die to a stray bomb you didn't account for.

There's some tactics involved, as the enemies may shoot each other if you maneuver smartly. As all robots might not shoot at the same time, attacking requires proper timing and patience, which I liked.

Just don't ram too eagerly or too far - it's easy to accidentally blast away from the level or bump too far backwards.

[h1]Controls and settings[/h1]

It's played exclusively with mouse. Ram follows the cursor, and left-click is for ramming. Sadly, the speed of the ramming didn't seem to matter for damage.

Settings involve muting sounds+music, switch between fullscreen and windowed, as well as clearing the save file (be careful not to do so accidentally, though - there's no prompt).

[h1][strike]But why not recommended?[/strike] EDIT: Fixed[/h1]

Game used to contain an achievement requiring the use of cheating software. This, and two broken achievements, were recently removed, so the game can be completed and perfected. Thus, I no longer have any problem recommending the game! (Thanks, dev!)

[h1]Conclusions[/h1]

Graphics are cute, and sound effects are a blast from the retro past.

My first playthrough lasted a bit over an hour, and I played it again right afterwards.

It's certainly a decent action game, and an easy recommendation for me! Particularly when on sale.

[url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/9997062/]~Twistorian Curator~[/url]

It's a good game but I have some suggestions.

1. Maybe add a "are you sure" screen when you click the delete progress to prevent people accidentally deleting progress by clicking the wrong thing. Happened to me, not a big deal but it would be nice to have that.

2. Maybe some levels could be themed instead of just the usual level. Examples: Christmas (snow), Halloween, space, etc.

3. Add a level creator so people can create their own levels and beat them so that the game doesn't get boring when you beat it.

Other than that this is a very good game. I'd say it's worth the $4, because it does take a long time to beat, and you have a lot of fun beating it.

72628915.review:
This is a Flash/browser/tablet tier game (which seems to be a PC native? How did that happen? These guys never heard of iphones?) where you control a sheep with one life that follows your mouse pointer around.  Clicking on the screen makes the sheep charge that location and potentially damage enemies.  Kill all the enemies without leaving the circle to progress.

Well the game works in full screen, which is the nicest thing that can be said about it.  And it doesn't use retro pixel graphics, just cartoony/MS paint style graphics.   Gameplay is really limited and simple.  The whole thing could have been done in flash and compares poorly to free browser/tablet games, yet they want you to pay $6 for this bundletrash.   You can buy real video games for the same price, or play better games free on mobile, so I can't recommend this.

66391463.review:
[quote][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/32732116-IndieGems/]Follow our curator page: [b]IndieGems[/b] if you like and want to see more reviews like this one.[/url][/quote]

[i]Battle Ram[/i] is an arcade style game with cute hand-drawn graphics that's entirely played with a mouse. While it has charming looks, it's missing a few crucial elements that would make the game much more than it is now. I would think that a base price of $3.99 is a bit high for a game that has such little content that has no variability. After 20 minutes or so I have reached a wall--so far insurmountable for myself. There is very little replay value in its bare-bones game at this time. So while I think the game has merit, the developer could take this as a building block to make something that's a lot more complex and exciting, thus enticing more audience members. 5.5/10 if you can get this on sale for about a dollar. Otherwise a bit of a let down compared to the screenshots and the trailer, which got me more excited than I felt actually playing.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
There's a story, it's not really something that makes sense, and you have to read it on the store page. The game just starts with no explanation, but for such a simple game, explanations are not necessary.

Play as the little ram, move him around using your mouse cursor. Click anywhere to perform an attack that shows the ram putting the head down and striking with its horns. Strike the robots that come or avoid the traps, and a single hit by anything, and you lose.

As far as I can tell, there are three different enemy types, benign-looking gray acorn-shaped robots that do not attack, blue meanies that remind me of a three-legged Shovel Knight that shoots one bullet at a time, and green drones that shoot series of three bullets. There are two different traps, rockets and light beams. Overall, your goal is to kill all of the enemies and avoid all of the traps in each level.

The individual levels consists of a single-screen arena where you goal is to survive to the end. There's a circle on the ground that you cannot step out of or get pushed out of, otherwise it's game over.

The levels save automatically so when you die, you start the same level, and if you hit a wall like I did with a particular level, that's it--expect to die repeatedly with no hope of survival after hitting this wall.

Thus I said above that this game is lacking in variability. You can play and have fun for a little while and when you hit the wall, it's the same level coming at you on repeat and all of the enemies move in the same pattern, and come in from the same angles every single time. there's no randomization of enemy types, spawn locations, etc. Each level is pre-made, making it seem really bland after losing the same level 15-20 times. 

The ram also only that one attack that I mentioned. So you can imagine, after not too long, you start wishing for a different way of attacking the enemies. 

[h1]Controls[/h1]
Mouse for movement and left click to perform your attack.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
Cute hand-drawn artwork, though there's not too much in terms of what to display.

[h1]Music & Sounds[/h1]
Work fine, no special sounds as far as I can tell.

[h1]Audience[/h1]
Very targeted audience who enjoys a good arcade-sim challenge and doesn't care about those above-mentioned things.

[h1]Pricing[/h1]
$3.99 US isn't not a high number, but high enough for anyone to hesitate in a game that lasts probably somewhere around 20-25 minutes before you hit that wall. Would probably seem rather short if you paid full price.

[h1]My First-Look Gameplay[/h1]
https://youtu.be/NUFZbuQlQeA

[h1]Potential Improvements[/h1]
-Randomize starting locations of enemies, so it doesn't feel like you are avoiding the same patterns of bullets each time.
-Add different weapons/attacks for the ram.
-Add a score reporting device--all arcade games should have a score tracker, with the scores or something only counts if you start from the beginning. 
-Game starting at the same level over and over again doesn't bode well. After not too long the game starts to feel a little old, especially if you hit that wall.
-All for resetting of the same file to at least replay the beginning parts. Best to just have a level selection screen where you can choose any of the levels that you have already progressed past.
-Having multiple save files would also be useful.
-Randomize some levels if possible, at least that would get you out of the same rut that you are stuck on on serial repeat.
-Hit boxes of the explosions seem a bit too large for me.
-Character modifiers would be cool to see how the gameplay may differ from run to run. Right now it's just a bit bland.
-Adding rooms to make the game varied as well. Currently there's just this one circular-room used. Enemies come in and try to take you out, either through the bullets/explosions, or they can push you out of the ring. 


[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
[i]Battle Ram[/i] is intrinsically not a bad game. I do think that there's a lot of areas of potential improvement that would make it a lot better from its current barebones self. With no variability and such little content, I think I would get it on a deep sale, otherwise you might feel that the gameplay time is not good compared to the price. I am going to give it a neutral curator review score, which fortunately I am able to do.

[quote]I received the product for free. I did not receive any compensation to write this review. The opinions represented here are entirely my own and were not influenced in any way.[/quote]

Awesome bullet hell. 
You can make a sequel outta this

65546979.review: This is a good arcade game. To get all the achievements, we need to beat the game the first time. The ram has only 1 life. The difficulty increases with each level. I really liked the graphics and music in this game.
